GameEngine
Class Game.GameInputInterface

java.lang.Object
  GameEngine.Game.GameInputInterface
Enclosing class:
Game
public class Game.GameInputInterface
extends java.lang.Object

This class is the interface to Java's Key and mouse input listeners. The standard java way of using Listeners does not apply fully when in a game as it runs on a separate thread. One needs to ensure that the input events do not fire during the logicStep phase and hence the game class acts as a buffer between the Listener events and the game loop.

The game class stores the current state of the keyboard and mouse inputs (is button x held down, was key z typed this frame etc). During the logic step is blocks all changes to this information and makes it read only, thus allowing the logic loop safe access to this information without fear of it being changed halfway through. After the logic step is completed, any KeyEvents or MouseEvents fired during the logicStep phase are logged and untill the logicStep is called again, any Events are logged as well.

This class ensures that the key/mouse inputs are only read from during the logicStep phase and not written (this makes use of Java syncornized methods for those interested to know).

Method Detail

keyDown

public boolean keyDown(int keyCode)
Returns whether this key is currently held down or not (true means the key is pressed down, false mean the key is currently not held down). Please note that if your GFPS is high, a key will usually register as being down over multiple frames. In some cases this is desired (e.g. holding down a direction button) but in other cases it is not (e.g. firing of a weapon). Additional logic should be built into your game to prevent unwanted behaviour. Or use keyTyped() method where applicable

Parameters:
keyCode - The key code as specified in the KeyEvent class
Returns:
Boolean value whether the key is currently held down.

mouseButtonDown

public boolean mouseButtonDown(int mouseButton)
Returns whether a mouse button is currently held down or not (true means the key is pressed down, false mean the key is currently not held down). Please note that if your GFPS is high, a mouse click will usually register as being down over multiple frames. In some cases this is desired (e.g. holding down a direction button) but in other cases it is not (e.g. firing of a weapon). Additional logic should be built into your game to prevent unwanted behaviour. Or use mouseClicked() method where applicable For the mouseButton parameter, it is as specified in MouseEvent (BUTTON1, BUTTON2 BUTTON3)

Parameters:
mouseButton - The mouse button as specified in the MouseEvent class
Returns:
Boolean value whether the mouse button is currently held down.

keyTyped

public boolean keyTyped(int keyCode)
Returns whether this key was typed (that it was pressed down and has just been released). This will return true as the key is released. This will only call once and will not go over multiple frames like the keyDown() method. If you want the key to register as being held down over multiple frames use the keyDown() method.

Parameters:
keyCode - The key code as specified in the KeyEvent class
Returns:
Boolean value whether the key was typed.

mouseButtonClicked

public boolean mouseButtonClicked(int mouseButton)
Returns whether this mouse button was clicked (that it was pressed down and has just been released). This will return true as the mouse button is released. This will only call once and will not go over multiple frames like the mouseuttonDown() method. If you want the mouse button to register as being held down over multiple frames use the mouseButtonDown() method. For the mouseButton parameter, it is as specified in MouseEvent (BUTTON1, BUTTON2 BUTTON3)

Parameters:
mouseButton - The key code as specified in the MouseEvent class
Returns:
Boolean value whether the mouse button was clicked.

mouseXScreenPosition

public int mouseXScreenPosition()
Returns the x coordinate of the mouse relative to the GameCanvas that it is attached to

Returns:
The x coordinate of the mouse

mouseYScreenPosition

public int mouseYScreenPosition()
Returns the y coordinate of the mouse relative to the GameCanvas that it is attached to

Returns:
The y coordinate of the mouse

mouseWheelScrollAmount

public int mouseWheelScrollAmount()
Returns how much the mouse wheel scrolled (relates to the MouseWheelEvent method getScrollAmount())

mouseWheelScrollType

public int mouseWheelScrollType()
Returns what type of scroll occured (relates to the MouseWheelEvent method getScrollType()).

mouseWheelUnitsToScroll

public int mouseWheelUnitsToScroll()
Returns the number of units to scroll(relates to the MouseWheelEvent method getUnitsToScroll()).

mouseWheelRotation

public int mouseWheelRotation()
Returns the mouse whell rotation, 1 or -1 (relates to the MouseWheelEvent method getUnitsToScroll()).

mouseDragged

public boolean mouseDragged()
Returns whether the mouse is currently being dragged. This method will return true no matter what button is beng pressed. If you wish to find out if BUTTON1 is being dragged, use this in conjunction with the mouseButtonDown() function

mouseMoved

public boolean mouseMoved()
Returns whether the mouse is currently being moved. Only returns true if mouse is being moved without a button being held down. So will return false if mouse is being dragged.
